item1.content: In order to secure the Fugger family's interests, Jacob Fugger went from Venice to Rome to preemt his dead brother

item2.content: After the adventic mass, Fugger met with archduke Sigmund and lent him 3'000 florins. That was one of his first important steps into becoming rich.

item3.smaller: Fugger became the owner of Salzburgian and Tyrolese mines and the Austrian mint
item3.content: After this transaction he boosted the extraction of silver and multiplied the mint's production 25 times.

item4.content: We don't have any proof, but it's highly presumable that on 339th Augsburg fair he met Maximilian Habsburg - the son of emperor Frederick. Maybe that time Fugger didn't know, but we do - this meeting was the key for the future Fugger's career.

item5.content: Fascinated by the copper resources of Hungary, Fugger and Jan Thurzo founded a trading company - Ungarischer Handel. Soon the company controlled the majority of Hungarian mines.

item6.content: To make Ungarischer Handel company's income safier, Fugger decided to build a fabric and a fortress in Arnoldstein. As we know from chronicles, this facilities looked ugly, but they were functionable which was the most important thing for Fugger and his company

item8.content: In that year, Fugger deponed up to 15'000 florins for building homeless shelters.

item9.content: Fuggerei is an Augsburg district built and founded by Jacob Fugger. This part of the city was another homeless shelter where the poorest could rent a flat for a pocket-size rent (around 0,88â‚¬ in today's currency).
